articleinfo.title: Fedict eID Trust Service Administrator Manual

abstract.para: This manual serves as an entry point for setting up the eID Trust Service.

section.title: Introduction
section.para:
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document (in uppercase, as shown) are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] . The eID Trust Service provides two major service artifacts:
eID Trust Service portal
Via this web portal citizens can check the validity of their eID certificates.
eID Trust Service validation web service
Via this SOAP web service Relying Parties (aka Service Providers) can check the validity of certificate paths. This web service is constructed according to the W3C XKMS2 web service standard.
Besides these two service artifacts, the eID Trust Service also comes with an Admin portal that allows administrators to manage the eID Trust Service via an easy to use web portal interface. In the following paragraphs we will use $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS as the (internal) web address where the eID Trust Service product has been deployed.

section.title: eID Trust Service Portal
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service product, the eID Trust Service Portal is available at $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal/. This web portal MUST be accessed over unilateral SSL. The SSL SHOULD be terminated on the front-end Apache HTTPD service so that the SSL information can be communicated to the JBoss Application Service over AJP. If such a setup is not possible this SHOULD be clearly communicated in advance to the eID Trust Service development team so they can properly configure the eID Applet Service that is used within the eID Trust Service Portal.

section.title: eID Trust Service Validation Web Service
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service product, the eID Trust Service validation web service is available at $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-ws/xkms2 This web service MUST be accessible via both HTTP and HTTPS (thus unilateral SSL). When this web service is accessed over plain HTTP, the service provides the possibility to sign the response messages using WS-Security.

section.title: eID Trust Service Admin Portal
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service, the eID Trust Service Admin Portal is available via: EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-admin-portal/. This web portal MUST be accessed over unilateral SSL.

section.title: SNMP
section.para: The eID Trust Service yields different SNMP counters on port 7894.

section.title: Database
section.para: The eID Trust Service product required a database to operate.

section.title: JBoss Application Server
section.para:
The JBoss Application Server offers:
AJP at port: 8009
HTTP at port: 8080
HTTPS at port: 8443
AJP is preferred for the connection between the front-end Apache HTTPD and the JBoss Application Server.

section.title: Installation
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with support for HSQL, MySQL and Oracle. This chapter explains how to initialize the database.

section.title: HSQL
section.para: If you wish to run the Fedict eID Trust Service using HSQL, you can use the JBoss distribution that comes with the Fedict eID Applet. Simply execute mvn jboss:deploy in the eid-trust-service-deploy artifact and you are good to go.
Beware though, as parsing large CRL's might be memory intensive, you can quickly run into memory issues on HSQL. Therefore it is only recommended to use this during a test setup.

section.title: MySQL
section.para: If you wish to run the Fedict eID Trust Service using MySQL, you can use the eid-trust-service-mysql-distribution artifact. After unpacking you first have to initialize your database. To do so, execute the sql scripts which can be found in /sql . The default username/password for the trust database is trust/trust . If you wish to change this, you will have to manually modify the sql scripts and change the datasource in the jboss distribution. The latter can be found in /jboss/server/default/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml .

section.title: SQuirrel SQL
section.para: To view the contents of the database behind the FedICT eID Trust Service, one can use the SQuirrel SQL Client . This SQL client allows you to view the structure of any JDBC compliant database.

To be able to connect to your HSQL/MySQL/Oracle database you will need to configure a JDBC driver. You can download the drivers @ MySQL JDBC Driver and
Oracle JDB Driver
. Configure your driver in SQuirrel SQL by selecting the appropriate one, select Modify Driver... and add your JDBC driver jar in the Extra Class Path tab.

When you are done with this, you can configure the connection to the database by adding a new Alias . Select the appropriate driver, and configure the URL, username and password as is configured in the FedICT eID Trust Service datasource file ( /jboss/server/default/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml ).

section.title: Transaction timeouts
section.para:
The downloading and processing of large CRLs can sometimes take alot of time. This can lead to internal transaction timeouts. By default, the custom JBoss MySQL and Oracle Distributions have a transaction timeout configured of 1200 seconds or 20 minutes. Which should be sufficient. If this still proves to be insufficient, this can be changed in jboss/server/default/deploy/transaction-jboss-beans.xml Look for following line and change accordingly:
<property name="defaultTimeout">1200</property>

section.title: Running
section.para: After you have correctly setup your database, you can start the application by ./jboss/bin/run.sh -b 0.0.0.0 . Note that in case you choose HSQL as your database, you will have to first start the Fedict eID Applet JBoss distribution, followed by running the command mvn jboss:deploy from the eid-trust-service-deploy artifact. The MySQL and Oracle distribution have the Fedict eID Trust Service Application packaged and will be started automatically.

After the application has started, it will have initialized itself with 4 trust domains.
eID Authentication Trust Domain
eID Non Repudiation Trust Domain
eID National Registry Trust Domain
Belgian TSA Trust Domain

The default trust domain will be set to the eID Authentication Trust Domain. In order to function properly, the application needs to be able to make outgoing calls for CRL, OCSP, TSP and NTP. If you are running behind a proxy, you can setup the proxy using the administration webapp.

section.title: Administration
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with an administration portal. This portal allows you to setup your network proxy if any, manage trust domains and other aspects of the service.

section.title: Administrator registration
section.para:
To authenticate to the administrator portal, an eID authentication will be performed. If the service was freshly installed, the first successfull authentication will be automatically registered as administrator. Subsequent administrators will have to be accepted by this one. There are two ways to accomplish this:
Perform a login which will add you as a pending administrator which can subsequently be approved by an administrator.
Ask another administrator who is logged to register you from within the admin portal. You can find this in the Configuration page.

section.title: Administrators
section.para: Here you can view existing and pending administrators, approve pending administrators, remove administratos and register an additional one. To register an additional one, a full eID authentication has to be performed of this new administrator.

section.title: WS Security Configuration
section.para: The eID Trust Service Validation Web Service has the possibility to optionally sign its response message using WS-Security. The keystore to be used for this can be configured here.

section.title: Network Configuration
section.para: If you are operating behind a proxy, you can setup this in here and enable or disable the proxy configuration temporarily.

section.title: Clock Drift Detection
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with built in support for NTP and TSP.

section.title: Information Message
section.para: The information message to be shown on $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal can be configured here for all available languages of the FedICT eID Trust Service Portal.

section.title: Virtual Trust Domains
section.para: Virtual trust domains are a group of existing trust domains. Users of the eID Trust Service Validation Web Service have the possibility to specify a virtual trust domain to validate against all of its trust domains configured.

section.title: Trust Domains
section.para: You can add, modify, remove trust domains here. Also you can set the default trust domain for the FedICT eID Trust Service. This trust domain will be used in the eID Trust Service Validation Web Service if no specific trust domain was specified. For each trust domain you can specify whether or not CRL caching should be used, which trust points lie under this trust domain and which certificate contraints are too be enforced when validating against this trust domain.

section.title: Trust Points
section.para: For each trust point, you can specify a cron expression for specifying the CRL cache refresh interval. Such a refresh includes refreshing all underlying CA's that have been cached. You can also refresh the CRL cache immediately here for debugging purposes. For each trust point you can see the list of CA's associated with this trust point and for each CA refresh the cache individually.

section.title: SNMP
section.para:
The FedICT eID Trust Service has several SNMP counters available. These counters can be retrieved by invoking the command:
snmpget -v 2c -c public localhost:7894 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.0.0
. The available SNMP counters are:
# of validations ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.0.0 )
# of CRL cache refreshes ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.1.0 )
# of CRL cache hits ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.2.0 )
# of CRL cache misses ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.3.0 )
CRL cache hit % ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.4.0 )
# of CRL download failures ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.5.0 )
# of OCSP request failures ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.6.0 )
